data.text:
The son of a railway porter and a domestic worker, Peterson was raised in Little Burgundy, the neighbourhood dubbed âHarlem of the Northâ which during MontrÃ©alâs Sin-City era was home to one of hottest jazz scenes on the planet. As Peterson once said, âI had to teach myself by being around the jazz that was being played in MontrÃ©al at that time. And there were quite a few good players.â

Oscarâs first piano teacher was his sister Daisy Peterson Sweeney who was a revered piano teacher in MontrÃ©alâs Black community and whose students included another MontrÃ©al jazz icon, Oliver Jones.

Oscar Peterson went on to win eight Grammys, including a Lifetime Achievement Award; his 1962 song âHymn to Freedomâ became an anthem of the Civil Rights Movement in America; he was awarded the Companion in the Order of Canada in 1984; and in 2005 became the first living Canadian ever honoured on a stamp.

Here are some MontrÃ©al landmarks honouring Oscar Peterson.

Honouring Oscar

In August 2021, the City of MontrÃ©al unveiled plans for Place Oscar-Peterson, a large public square that will be created during the reconstruction of McGill College Avenue in the heart of downtown. The square will be located between Saint Catherine Street and de Maisonneuve Boulevard, and will include a statue of Peterson and other art installations celebrating his life and work.

âFor more than 60 years, Oscar Peterson played around the world, he was an inspiration to generations of MontrÃ©al musicians,â Mayor ValÃ©rie Plante told reporters. âAlthough he achieved worldwide fame, Oscar Peterson remained very attached to MontrÃ©al and composed many pieces about his home city, including âPlace St. Henriâ which is one of his classics.â

Oscarâs widow Kelly Peterson said MontrÃ©al âdidnât give him his talent, of course, but its influences shaped him throughout his life. He was so very proud to have been born in MontrÃ©al, to have grown up in MontrÃ©al, to come back to play the MontrÃ©al International Jazz Festival.â

Work on Place Oscar-Peterson is expected to begin in 2023, and Plante hopes it will be completed in time for the 100th anniversary of Petersonâs birth in 2025.

Oscar-worthy landmarks

While Little Burgundy was the epicentre of MontrÃ©alâs Sin City-era jazz scene, Peterson in 1947 began a residency at the downtown Alberta Lounge at the corner of De la GauchetiÃ¨re and Peel streets, where the Chateau Champlain Hotel is located today. Peterson was discovered there by legendary American jazz impresario Norman Granz in 1949, then made his American debut at Carnegie Hall later that year.

Growing up in Little Burgundy, Peterson attended the historic Union United Church (3007 Delisle Street), founded in 1907 by Black railway porters and their wives. Today, a nearby park in Little Burgundy is named after Peterson.

The neighbourhood is also home to two monumental murals of note: the Jazz Born Here mural of Oscar by artist Gene Pendon, located at the corner of Saint Jacques and des Seigneurs streets; and the Tribute to Daisy Peterson Sweeney mural by artist Kevin Ledo, at the corner of Saint Jacques and Saint Martin streets.

In addition to teaching thousands of students â including her younger brother Oscar â to play piano, Daisy Peterson Sweeney in 1974 co-founded the MontrÃ©al Black Community Youth Choir at Union United Church, the choir which in 1982 became the famed MontrÃ©al Jubilation Gospel Choir under the direction of Dr. Trevor Payne.
